attributes.title: Waribashi - Disposable chopsticks
attributes.description:
Created on June 1, 2010 by ckwan on Sourcemap.org:

There are many types of waribashi, or disposiable chopsticks.  Some are made of bamboo, others are made of wood and there are differing qualities.  Malaysian, Vietnamese, Chinese and Canadian forests have all been clear cut for manufacture of these avoidable chopsticks.  This habit of disposable chopsticks contributes heavily to deforestation.   According to Japan Times: 
The Japanese government's Forestry Agency estimates that a whopping 25 billion pairs of waribashi are used in Japan every year â which translates to about 200 pairs per man, woman and child inhabiting the archipelego.

That's equivalent to the amount of timber required to build 17,000 houses of 120 sq. meters in size.

http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fe20080730a1.html
